title: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
scope: ** Diagnosis and acute management of ADEM in children and adults. Covers IPMSSG diagnostic criteria, distinction from first MS attack, MOGAD-associated ADEM, CSF analysis, immunotherapy (high-dose steroids, IVIg, PLEX), and monitoring for recurrence. Includes multiphasic ADEM (MDEM) considerations. Excludes other causes of acute encephalitis unless as differential diagnosis.

Essential Studies.target: Large (>1-2 cm), poorly demarcated, bilateral, asymmetric white matter lesions; deep gray matter (thalami, basal ganglia) involvement common in ADEM; may enhance with contrast

Essential Studies.timing: Within 24 hours; assess for concurrent myelitis
Essential Studies.target: Large, longitudinally extensive, intramedullary T2 lesions (often ≥3 segments); may enhance

Essential Studies.timing: Only if MRI not immediately available; exclude mass, hemorrhage, hydrocephalus
Essential Studies.target: No acute hemorrhage or mass; may show subtle white matter hypodensity

Extended Studies.target: Diffuse or focal slowing without epileptiform activity; epileptiform discharges if seizures

Extended Studies.timing: Document lesion resolution (ADEM lesions should partially or fully resolve); new lesions suggest MS or MOGAD relapse
Extended Studies.target: Resolution or significant improvement of lesions; no new lesions
Elevated choline, reduced NAA in acute lesion; no mass-like spectral pattern

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line for ADEM; begin as soon as CNS infection reasonably excluded; do NOT delay for LP results if clinical suspicion high

dosing.instructions: Pediatric: 30 mg/kg/day (max 1000 mg) IV daily x 3-5 days; Adult: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days; infuse over 1 hour

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated bacterial/fungal infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Blood glucose Q6H; BP; mood/sleep; GI symptoms; electrolytes

Acute/Emergent.indication: Following IV methylprednisolone; prevents rebound; do NOT taper faster than 4 weeks

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) after IV pulse; taper by 5-10 mg q3-5d over 4-6 weeks; do NOT taper faster than 4 weeks (risk of relapse)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Blood glucose; BP; mood; weight; GI protection (PPI)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric coverage for HSV encephalitis until PCR results return; ADEM and HSV can present similarly

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV q8h; continue until HSV PCR confirmed negative (typically 48-72h); ensure adequate hydration

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function (Cr); adequate hydration (prevent crystalluria); CBC

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) over 2 min; may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg

Acute/Emergent.indication: GI ulcer prophylaxis during high-dose steroid therapy

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizures in ADEM; preferred first-line anticonvulsant due to fewer drug interactions and no hepatic metabolism

dosing.instructions: Loading dose 20-30 mg/kg IV (max 3000 mg); then 500-1000 mg BID; adjust for renal function; may taper after 3-6 months if seizure-free and EEG normalized

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Mood changes (rage, irritability); sedation; suicidality screening; renal function

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d; target 300-900 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day divided TID

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if liver disease); pediatric: 15 mg/kg q6h (max 75 mg/kg/day)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects; cognitive effects (especially elderly and children); dry mouth

Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.indication: Steroid-refractory ADEM (no improvement after 3-5 days of IV steroids); contraindication to steroids

dosing.instructions: 2 g/kg total divided over 2-5 days (0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days); premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine; check IgA level before first dose

Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.contraindications: IgA deficiency with anti-IgA antibodies; recent thromboembolic event; uncompensated HF; renal failure
Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.monitoring: Renal function; headache (aseptic meningitis); infusion reactions; BP; HR; thrombotic events

Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.indication: Steroid-refractory and IVIg-refractory ADEM; severe fulminant ADEM (AHLE variant)

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per session; albumin replacement

Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability; severe coagulopathy; poor vascular access; sepsis
Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.monitoring: Coagulation studies (fibrinogen); electrolytes (calcium, potassium, magnesium); BP; hemodynamic monitoring; line site

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily; extend course to 7-10 days total if partial response after initial 3-5 days
dosing.orderSentence: Repeat IV Methylprednisolone (extended course) 1000 mg IV

Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; steroid psychosis
Second-line/Refractory (Steroid-Refracto.monitoring: Glucose q6h; BP; mood; infection surveillance; electrolytes

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for ADEM diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy management, and MS/MOGAD/NMOSD differentiation
Neuroradiology review of MRI for ADEM vs MS lesion pattern characterization
Infectious disease consultation if infection cannot be confidently excluded or if unusual pathogen suspected
Physical therapy for motor recovery, gait training, and rehabilitation planning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and adaptive strategies during recovery
Speech-language pathology for dysphagia assessment and communication if brainstem/cerebellar involvement
Neuropsychology follow-up for cognitive assessment (cognitive deficits may persist especially in children)
Ophthalmology if optic neuritis component present for visual acuity monitoring and OCT baseline
Rehabilitation medicine for comprehensive inpatient rehabilitation if significant residual motor or cognitive deficits
Social work for family support, insurance navigation, school/work accommodations, and discharge planning
Pediatric neurology referral if pediatric patient (ADEM most common in children ages 5-8)

Patient Instructions.item: ADEM is usually a monophasic illness with good recovery expected over weeks to months; most patients (>70%) recover fully or near-fully
Return to ED immediately if new neurological symptoms develop after discharge (new weakness, vision changes, confusion, seizures) as this may indicate relapse or alternative diagnosis (MS, MOGAD)
Complete the full oral steroid taper as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of disease rebound and adrenal crisis)
Follow-up MRI at 3-6 months is essential to confirm lesion resolution and rule out MS (new lesions on follow-up MRI would suggest MS rather than ADEM)
Report any new visual symptoms, limb weakness, numbness, or balance problems even after recovery, as these may indicate a second attack (MDEM or MS transition)
Report any signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria) while on steroid therapy, as steroids suppress immune function
Avoid driving and operating heavy machinery while on sedating medications (levetiracetam, gabapentin) until tolerance established
Children: inform school of diagnosis and potential cognitive recovery needs; request neuropsychological testing before return

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Adequate rest during acute recovery; gradual return to school/work activities as neurological function improves
Vaccination review: ADEM can rarely be triggered by vaccines; this does NOT contraindicate future vaccination in most cases; discuss with neurologist and immunologist on case-by-case basis
Seizure precautions if seizures occurred during acute phase; anticonvulsant taper guided by neurology (usually can be discontinued if EEG normalizes and seizure-free for 3-6 months)
Balanced diet with adequate calcium and vitamin D intake during steroid therapy; monitor weight
Avoid contact sports and high-risk activities until neurological recovery is complete and cleared by neurology
Stress management and psychological support; ADEM diagnosis can be distressing for patients and families; consider counseling if adjustment difficulties

differential.features: No encephalopathy (key distinction); well-demarcated periventricular lesions; Dawson fingers; OCBs positive; lesions disseminated in time and space
differential.tests: MRI (periventricular, juxtacortical, Dawson fingers); CSF OCBs (positive in >90% MS); follow-up MRI showing new lesions at 3-6 months

differential.features: Overlap with ADEM especially in children; MOG-IgG positive; may relapse (unlike monophasic ADEM); optic neuritis and myelitis common
differential.tests: MOG-IgG (cell-based assay); clinical course (relapses suggest MOGAD vs monophasic ADEM)

differential.features: AQP4-IgG positive; area postrema syndrome; longitudinally extensive TM; optic neuritis; less commonly encephalopathy
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG antibody; MRI pattern (LETM, area postrema); clinical features

differential.features: Temporal lobe predilection; hemorrhagic lesions; rapid deterioration; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis with RBCs
differential.tests: CSF HSV PCR (positive); MRI (temporal lobe T2 hyperintensity with hemorrhagic changes); EEG (PLEDs)

differential.features: Psychiatric symptoms; seizures; movement disorder (faciobrachial dystonic seizures in LGI1); ovarian teratoma (NMDAR)
differential.tests: Autoimmune antibody panel (serum and CSF); MRI (may be normal or limbic involvement)

differential.features: Direct viral invasion; more pronounced meningeal signs; CSF viral PCR positive; no demyelinating lesion pattern on MRI
differential.tests: CSF viral PCR panel; MRI pattern (cortical > white matter); clinical course

differential.features: Multifocal lesions but with vascular territory pattern; vessel wall enhancement on MRI; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: MR angiography; vessel wall MRI; conventional angiography; brain biopsy

differential.features: Periventricular enhancing mass(es); older adults; immunocompromised; homogeneous enhancement
differential.tests: MRI (homogeneous enhancement); CSF cytology and flow cytometry; brain biopsy

differential.features: Hyperacute fulminant variant of ADEM; hemorrhagic white matter necrosis; very high mortality
differential.tests: MRI (hemorrhagic component); brain biopsy (if diagnostic uncertainty); clinical course (fulminant)

differential.features: Leptomeningeal enhancement; cranial neuropathies; hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated ACE
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT (hilar adenopathy); CSF (ACE, cell count); brain biopsy if needed

monitoring.item: Neurological examination (motor, sensory, cerebellar, mental status)
monitoring.action: Escalate to IVIg or PLEX if no improvement after 3-5 days of IV steroids
Escalate treatment; consider intubation if GCS declining; ICU transfer
Sliding scale insulin; scheduled insulin if persistent
New lesions suggest MS or MOGAD relapse; refer for long-term DMT consideration
Persistent positivity increases relapse risk; consider longer steroid taper or maintenance therapy
Neuropsychological referral; educational support for children

monitoring.frequency: During hospitalization; follow-up EEG if seizures occurred
monitoring.action: Continue anticonvulsant; EEG monitoring; consider tapering anticonvulsant at 3-6 months if seizure-free

disposition.criteria: All patients with confirmed or suspected ADEM; need for IV methylprednisolone; neurological monitoring; infection exclusion
Severe encephalopathy (GCS ≤12); respiratory compromise; status epilepticus; rapidly deteriorating neurological exam; AHLE variant
Neurologically improving; tolerating oral prednisone taper; no seizures; adequate oral intake; safe for home environment; follow-up MRI and neurology appointments scheduled
All patients: 2-4 weeks post-discharge; 3-month follow-up MRI; 6-month and 12-month visits to monitor for relapse; longer follow-up if MOG-IgG positive
